items.title: Issue running --with-timer and --process at the same time
items.body:
Please look at plugin.py line 258

The line
            _results_queue.put((test.id(), time_taken, None))
Should be
            _results_queue.put((test.id(), time_taken, status))

The resulting bug is that timer prints [None] for the status instead of the status.

items.title: Failing red tests, possibly with exceptions
items.body:
Hi, 
Thank you for this great plugin, I'm finding it very useful for quality assurance on tests.
I would like to put in a feature request for having an option to fail tests if they exceed the warning threshold. 

In other words, 'red' or 'error' classifications will be failed with an error message like "All the assertions in this test passed, but the test itself was slower than the allowed threshold of <n> seconds". 

Along with this, it would be nice to have the option to pass in the python path of certain tests that should be excluded from failing based on time. For example parameters like 
    --ignore-time-for-test=tests.MyTestClass.test_this --ignore-time-for-test=tests.MyTestClass2.test_this2
This would be useful if we have a good reason why some tests should run for longer than the normal threshold. 

I would be happy to make contributions to implement the above.

items.title: Automated performance asserts at the test level
items.body:
Feature request:

Although _--timer-warning/--timer-ok_ flags already provide the ability to highlight tests in a running time range, some tests have specific performance goals (specially integration tests). Additionally, sometimes, getting the console output in a target-remote environment is not trivial.

Given that, I proposed that nose-timer provide the ability to specify an upper bound time for each test. It could be accomplished by using [annotations](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3107/), as [nose2dep does](https://github.com/rkday/nose2dep#dependencies) (image below)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1585655/36206058-c4684a00-116f-11e8-9e3b-88247c5a5a3d.png)

We could have an annotation as:
`@time_limit(value=15, unit='ms')`

items.title: One test seems to always have additional overhead.
items.body:
Hi, 

If I'm not mistaken, 2 functions with the exact same code should show me similar times and percentages unless the the context in which they're run is different which and causes more delays when running one of the functions.

I first thought it could be the order in which the tests are run but -v shows me the same order every time, but not the same function being the "outlier".  

I guess this could be an issue with the OS and that I shouldn't expect this to be a benchmark since the tests are only being run once, but I'm puzzled as to why it is that might be causing the problem.

Below is the sample code/unit test and the results of some runs.

```python
import unittest
'''
Simple sample function:

get multiply all items in a vector by x,
square them and provide result 

The goal is to show how one test, 
the one that is probably run first,
seems to take longer than the rest.
'''


def one(vec, x):
    return list(map(lambda c: (x*c)**2, vec))


def one_clone(vec, x):
    return list(map(lambda c: (x*c)**2, vec))


def two(vec, x):
    resvec = []
    for v in vec:
        resvec.append((v * x)**2)
    return resvec


def two_clone(vec, x):
    resvec = []
    for v in vec:
        resvec.append((v * x)**2)
    return resvec


class TestNoseTimer(unittest.TestCase):
    def setUp(self):
        self.vec = list(range(5))
        self.factor = 5
        self.expected = [0, 25, 100, 225, 400]

    def test_one(self):
        result = one(self.vec, self.factor)
        self.assertEquals(result, self.expected)

    def test_one_clone(self):
        result = one_clone(self.vec, self.factor)
        self.assertEquals(result, self.expected)

    def test_two(self):
        result = two(self.vec, self.factor)
        self.assertEquals(result, self.expected)

    def test_two_clone(self):
        result = two_clone(self.vec, self.factor)
        self.assertEquals(result, self.expected)


if __name__ == "__main__":
    unittest.main()
```

```bash
hackerrank$ nosetests -v --with-timer test_nose_timer.py 
test_one (test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer) ... ok (0.0002s)
test_one_clone (test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer) ... ok (0.0001s)
test_two (test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer) ... ok (0.0001s)
test_two_clone (test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer) ... ok (0.0001s)

[success] 41.86% test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer.test_one: 0.0002s
[success] 22.49% test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer.test_one_clone: 0.0001s
[success] 18.31% test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer.test_two_clone: 0.0001s
[success] 17.34% test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer.test_two: 0.0001s
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 4 tests in 0.001s

OK
hackerrank$ nosetests -v --with-timer test_nose_timer.py 
test_one (test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer) ... ok (0.0002s)
test_one_clone (test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer) ... ok (0.0001s)
test_two (test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer) ... ok (0.0001s)
test_two_clone (test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer) ... ok (0.0001s)

[success] 44.36% test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer.test_one: 0.0002s
[success] 20.54% test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer.test_one_clone: 0.0001s
[success] 17.83% test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer.test_two_clone: 0.0001s
[success] 17.26% test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer.test_two: 0.0001s
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 4 tests in 0.001s

OK
hackerrank$ nosetests -v --with-timer test_nose_timer.py 
test_one (test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer) ... ok (0.0001s)
test_one_clone (test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer) ... ok (0.0002s)
test_two (test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer) ... ok (0.0000s)
test_two_clone (test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer) ... ok (0.0001s)

[success] 41.52% test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer.test_one_clone: 0.0002s
[success] 32.04% test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer.test_one: 0.0001s
[success] 16.32% test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer.test_two_clone: 0.0001s
[success] 10.12% test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer.test_two: 0.0000s
----------------------------------------------------------------------

hackerrank$ nosetests -v --with-timer test_nose_timer.py 
test_one (test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer) ... ok (0.0002s)
test_one_clone (test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer) ... ok (0.0001s)
test_two (test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer) ... ok (0.0000s)
test_two_clone (test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer) ... ok (0.0001s)

[success] 56.85% test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer.test_one: 0.0002s
[success] 18.19% test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer.test_two_clone: 0.0001s
[success] 13.65% test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer.test_one_clone: 0.0001s
[success] 11.30% test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer.test_two: 0.0000s
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 4 tests in 0.001s

OK
```


If I add a time.sleep(1) and a time.sleep(2) to my one/one_clone and two/two_clone functions respectively, the results are exactly what I would expect:

```bash
hackerrank$ nosetests -v --with-timer test_nose_timer.py 
test_one (test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer) ... ok (1.0010s)
test_one_clone (test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer) ... ok (1.0024s)
test_two (test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer) ... ok (2.0025s)
test_two_clone (test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer) ... ok (2.0035s)

[success] 33.34% test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer.test_two_clone: 2.0035s
[success] 33.32% test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer.test_two: 2.0025s
[success] 16.68% test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer.test_one_clone: 1.0024s
[success] 16.66% test_nose_timer.TestNoseTimer.test_one: 1.0010s
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 4 tests in 6.013s

OK
```

btw, looking at your code I've just found out about parametrized.  Thanks for that! :)

items.title: Benchmark results change formatting mid-run
items.body:
Found that running a test suite with verbose=3 outputs the benchmark results in two different ways (regardless if evaluated as ok/warning/error), switching between them halfway through (even including an empty newline):

`test_some.Test.test ... ok (0.0001s)

test_other.Test.test: 0.4821s`

I haven't found anything about output formatting options in the README.

items.title: Running the test suite with the plugin messes up test case sorting
items.body: Running the tests with verbose=3 processes and outputs test cases in alphabetical order. Except when running it with the timer plugin, which messes up this order. It is but a minor annoyance, but an annoyance all the same.

items.title: Installing the plugin breaks a test on OS X El Capitan
items.body:
Installing the plugin breaks a test with TimeoutError (regardless of running them with or without benchmarking). After uninstall, the test works just fine.

Setup: Python 2.7, OS X El Capitan (it works with the same Python version on a Yosemite setup)

Test case structure: The test starts up a flask server as a subprocess, then issues an HTTP request against it. This is the request which times out.

items.title: Why BSD 4-Clause?
items.body: Trying to understand why the BSD 4-Clause is present here. It is known that the advertising clause causes [serious problems](http://www.gnu.org/licenses/bsd.en.html). So, I am trying to understand why it was added and whether it can be removed (i.e. the license converted to BSD 3-Clause or similar).

items.title: Write time-statistics to file
items.body: I would like to save statistics on file to be able to spot potential regressions performance-wise. Could some option be added to save a machine-readable format of the data nose-timer produces?

items.title: PyPy3 and Python 3.2 timeout and error builds
items.body:
```
$ coverage run --append --include=PIL/* -m nose -vx Tests/test_*.py --with-timer --timer-top-n 10 --timer-ok 1s --timer-warning 10s
No output has been received in the last 10 minutes, this potentially indicates a stalled build or something wrong with the build itself.
The build has been terminated
```

See https://travis-ci.org/hugovk/nose-timer/builds/42836302 and https://travis-ci.org/mahmoudimus/nose-timer/builds/42836459

This prevents nose-timer being used on projects which need to support PyPy3 and Python 3.2.

items.title: Colour on Travis CI
items.body:
Is it possible to use colour on Travis CI? 

[This build](https://travis-ci.org/hugovk/Pillow/jobs/32728769) uses this command with both `--timer-ok` and `--timer-warning` flags:

```
coverage run --append --include=PIL/* -m nose -vx Tests/test_*.py --with-timer --timer-top-n 10 --timer-ok 1s --timer-warning 10s
```

There are some tests taking up to 46 seconds, but it's all in black and white.

Am I missing something, or is it not possible to use colour with Travis CI?

items.title: Timer options
items.body:
Guys, currently I see a problem with using the `--timer-ok` and `--timer-warning` options.
When the `--timer-ok` option is used it is expected that all tests which take less time than `--timer-ok` will be highlighted in green. The same with `--timer-warning`. But let's imagine somebody used the `--timer-warning` option only with value < 1s and expects to see all tests that took less time than `--timer-warning` in yellow, other - in red. But this will never happen, since all tests passed **less** then the `--timer-ok` (which is 1s by default) and they are marked as 'ok'. Yes, this a bit confusing.

I would propose to treat  these option as **thresholds** of maximum pass time and use the `--timer-error` and `--time-warning` options. So the `--timer-error` will color all tests with red, if test took **more** time then specified threshold. The same with `--time-warning`. I think this is more natural (maybe I wrong). 

Moreover, to prevent situations when these options intersect I think in case when at least one threshold specified - the default values should not be taken into account.

Folks, what are your thoughts?

items.title: Nose Timer doesn't work with multiprocess
items.body:
In order to run my tests faster, I use the multiprocess module and run my tests in parallel, like so:

```
$ nosetests ... --processes=4
```

When I try to run my tests with Nose Timer, I don't see any timer results:

```
$ nosetests ... --processes=4 --with-timer
```

It works fine when I drop "--processes=4"

KeyError: 'test_stuff.TestGLM.test_one'

items.title: Have timings show up on the same line as the test.
items.body: It would be great if timings would show up on the same line as the test when run like `nosetests -vv --with-timer --timer-verbose`. I don't know if this is possible, but would definitely be preferable.

items.title: Please, tag releases :)
items.body: #8 was closed with 0.2.0 uploaded to pypi, but the release was never tagged.  I'm using the old gist, currently, and will switch over to nose-timer soon.  I'm also considering building a deb package that may eventually go to the Debian Python Modules Team, if I get some time.  A well organized upstream project helps, wrt Debian packaging  :)

items.title: Create roadmap
items.body: Create Roadmap file with plans for features in future releases

items.title: Test the timer using Tox
items.body: Write some simple tests to ensure no regression and that the timer works across all python versions up to python 3.3.

items.title: Provide a way for the plugin to dump a data file with timings
items.body: The datafile can then be used by other 3rd party tools to track/graph slow tests over time

items.title: Add a vagrantfile
items.body: For individuals who want to start hacking on it.

items.title: Make the README prettier
items.body: Let's properly format the README file - include contributors, license, usage, quickstart, and travis CI integration

items.title: Travis CI integration
items.body: We should have travis ci integration for this project.

items.title: Publish a new PyPI version
items.body: The latest available version is https://pypi.python.org/pypi/nose-timer/0.1.2, which was published in September 2012

items.title: Add support for "tests slower than X"
items.body: Some kind of interface like  --max-runtime=50 where 50 is the number of milliseconds for a test to run would be really nice, to avoid printing the timing results of every single test.

items.title: Document the supported nose timer API
items.body: Does this only support the --with-timer flag? it looks like a PR was merged for the N slowest tests, what is the interface for that/why isn't it in the help documentation for nosetests?

items.title: Colorize test execution time output
items.body: Colorize output according to test execution time. E.g. if test takes more then 1sec - yellow, >3 sec - red, <1 sec - green. Time limits for tests should be parameterized.
